+Mike King
That's not factually true.  To make a sweeping statement like that (as much 
as I hate "Hip Hop") would discount the overwhelming evidence of social 
trends in the 19th century.

States (and by this, I mean countries) were becoming more and more 
conscious of human rights.  In fact, there was a trend against doing 
business with other states that took advantage of slave labor because the 
world of the 19th century was becoming economically dependent on imports.  
If someone else could get you goods at bottom dollar and be ethically 
clean, then they would be your country's goto.  While it is true that the 
southern United States may have continued using slave labor, they would 
have been economically hurting as their gross exports declined every year.

On another note, your comment completely discounts the musical scenes of 
every other culture in the world.  If we are to assume that "Hip Hop" is a 
product of slave culture and African music, then we can look to Haiti, or 
the French colony of Saint Domingue, as it freed itself from both slavery 
and French rule in the early 19th century (about half a century before the 
American Civil War).  It's quite possible that "blues" music could have 
found a niche in that society, which could have ultimately culminated in 
"Hip Hop."

Not everything in history is perfectly linear.

This is what mirrors the infinite clash of ethics and morals. It is certain 
that legal ethics must override personal morals for the greater good of 
upholding a justice system in which the accused are given a fair trial, and 
subsequently so the judges must abide by that rule and maintain an 
objective position... But this can be a very difficult task. At the end of 
the day, we are all human, and we all have our moral codes, but there is 
variety in the intensity of our moral sensitivity. I presume this judge 
wholeheartedly understood the pain of the victims, and combined with the 
criminal's reprehensible behavior this resulted in him not bearing the 
murderer's obnoxious laughing. Although I agree judges should not allow 
their personal feelings to interfere with their objectively meant work, I 
wouldn't really blame them if they had an outburst in such particularities. 
I myself can not even fathom how someone could have the audacity to laugh 
in court, knowing the magnitude of their crime, and that is probably what 
flashed through the judges's mind in the heat of the moment. You must keep 
in mind he does not witness this from behind his computer or television, he 
was faced with it as an involved party right in the moment it'self. He had 
scarcely time to even take in what happened, or cool off. Now don't get me 
wrong, he acted on his anger, and therefore his action deserves to be 
criticized, but only to an extent, especially since this case is most 
likely an irregularity. He much less deserves to be criticized as a person.﻿
